title: 103_s1737
content: The General Accounting Office Oversight and Improvement Act of 1993 establishes the Office of Inspector General within the General Accounting Office, in accordance with the Inspector General Act of 1978. The Inspector General Act of 1978 is amended to include special provisions concerning the General Accounting Office. The Inspector General Act of 1978 is amended to include provisions for the appointment of the Inspector General of the Office of the Inspector General for the General Accounting Office. The General Accounting Office is established as an establishment under this Act, with the Comptroller General of the United States as its head. The Inspector General is appointed jointly by the Majority Leader and Minority Leader of the Senate, as well as the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Minority Leader of the House of Representatives. The Inspector General can only be removed from office for specific reasons such as permanent disability, inefficiency, neglect of duty, malfeasance, or a felony. An Inspector General removed under these conditions cannot be reappointed. Additionally, the Comptroller General of the United States and the General Accounting Office are involved in the appointment process. The General Accounting Office is involved in the appointment process of the Inspector General. SEC. 103 amends Section 5315 of title 5, United States Code to include the Inspector General, General Accounting Office. SEC. 104 allows the Comptroller General to reorganize the Office of Special Investigations for greater efficiency. SEC. 201 requires final reports and congressional requests for reports. The Comptroller General shall provide agencies with an opportunity to review findings before final reports are released. The agency response will be included in the final report. The Comptroller General must include organizational contacts and sources of information in final reports. If a Member of Congress requests to withhold a report, it can be released after 7 days. A final report can only be released if the General Accounting Office has followed internal quality control procedures. Congressional requests for reports must be acknowledged within 3 days. The Comptroller General must notify relevant congressional leaders within 3 days of approving a report request. Notifications of approvals must be published in the Congressional Record. The Comptroller General must notify congressional leaders of approved report requests within 3 days, and such approvals shall be published in the Congressional Record. Requests from committee chairmen and ranking members will be treated equally. A technical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 7 of title 5, United States Code. The General Accounting Office Peer Review Committee is established, referred to as the "Committee". Membership details are outlined. The General Accounting Office Peer Review Committee, known as the "Committee," is established with membership details. The Committee consists of up to 15 members, including 2 Senators and 2 Members of the House of Representatives, each from different political parties. Members are appointed by the Comptroller General from nominations by Senate and House leaders. The Chairman is designated by the Comptroller General, and vacancies are filled as needed. The Committee consists of 15 members, including 2 Senators and 2 Members of the House of Representatives from different parties. It also includes 2 Inspectors General, 2 individuals not federal officers, and 7 members with expertise in federal administrative policymaking. The Comptroller General serves as a nonvoting ex officio member. Members do not receive compensation, and travel expenses are covered. Members of the Committee who are not Federal officers and employees are allowed travel expenses, including per diem, at authorized rates while away from home for Committee services. SEC. 303. FUNCTIONS OF THE COMMITTEE. The Committee will recommend a process for agencies and affected parties to appeal factual errors in General Accounting Office reports, notify Congress and the public of modifications, and review and improve guidelines to prevent advocacy of policy in reports. The Committee will recommend improvements to ensure that General Accounting Office work product is fair, factual, unbiased, professional, and consistent with its purposes. This includes reviewing internal quality control procedures and recommending procedures for requesters to remain anonymous. The General Accounting Office team members oversee investigations, review policies, estimate costs, and make recommendations to improve professionalism and reduce compliance costs. The General Accounting Office team members oversee investigations, review policies, estimate costs, and make recommendations to improve professionalism, impartiality, independence, excellence, hiring practices, employee training, morale, administrative structure, and policies to further the office's purposes. SEC. 304. IMPLEMENTATION OF RECOMMENDATIONS. The Comptroller General will implement Committee recommendations to the extent possible, submitting a report to Congress upon the Committee's termination. Any recommendations unable to be implemented will be notified to Congress with reasons. SEC. 305. SUPPORT SERVICES. SEC. 305. SUPPORT SERVICES. The General Accounting Office will provide administrative and support services for the Committee. SEC. 306. FEDERAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE ACT. The Federal Advisory Committee Act provisions will not apply to the Committee. SEC. 307. TERMINATION OF COMMITTEE. The Committee will terminate 1 year after the enactment of this Act.
